isis.stitle: INTERNATIONAL® VT 365 DIESEL ENGINE - ENGINE SYSTEMS - Engine Systems - Cooling System

svcsubproc.title: Description

figure.caption: Figure 21. Engine coolant flow diagram and system components

svcsubproc.para: The function of the cooling system is to keep the engine within a designated temperature range. Major components include a thermostat, EGR cooler, oil cooler, radiator and fan combination with a coolant (water) pump. The water pump is a belt-driven centrifugal type, which is contained in the front cover.

The front cover incorporates several separate passages. Two passages channel coolant to the crankcase and heads from the water pump, two passages channel returning coolant from the crankcase and heads, and a bypass to route coolant back into the water pump when the thermostat is closed. See Appendix A for thermostat start-to-open temperature and fully open temperature.

Coolant flows from the radiator into the inlet tube of the front cover and into the water pump. The coolant is pushed by the water pump, through the front cover and into the crankcase. Crankcase coolant flows from the front to the rear, and is evenly distributed around the cylinders and through the cylinder heads. Cylinder head coolant flows up from the rear to the front of the heads. Coolant returns to the front cover through passages in the crankcase.

When the engine coolant temperature is below the specified start-to-open temperature (see Appendix A), the coolant flows through the bypass passage to the water pump because the radiator outlet port is blocked. As the engine reaches operating temperature, the thermostat opens, directing coolant through the radiator, and restricts the bypass opening.
